field_edited_text.value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways



located at greater distances from expressways. Approximately 500 sales
were investigated and in each case an interview was conducted with both
the seller and the buyer. The houses adjoining the expressway were
located from 75 to 200 feet from the expressway traffic with the majority
of the houses being within 150 feet. Most of the houses were at the same
level as the expressway or at a lower level.

The results of the study showed that the sales prices for houses
adjoining the expressway were approximately 1% to 29% lower than the
houses away from the expressway. This difference is hardly large enough
to be significant. In the course of the interviews 429, of the residents
living adjacent to expressways indicated that the noise did not bother
them, 339 were recorded as having “slight objection,” and 109 stated
that they were bothered only by trucks. The remaining 159% found the
noise objectionable. In response to a question on their general reaction
to the location, 48% of the residents living adjacent to expressways stated
that they felt the location was “no better or worse than other areas.”
239, preferred an expressway location while 20% did not like the express-
way location. The remaining 9% had a mixed reaction.

Additional evidence along the same line is available in current resi-
dential development along the County Beltway. In the general vicinity of
Towson a substantial number of houses have been built and sold on land
adjoining the Beltway. Apparently the purchasers did not regard the
proximity of the Beltway as being objectionable.

As a generality it can be said that an expressway will have an adverse
effect upon adjacent properties in any case where the expressway is less
attractive or less desirable than the use which it replaces and that, con-
versely, an expressway may have a beneficial effect when the opposite is
the case. Thus, almost any kind of expressway adjacent to a high-grade
residential area will act, at least to some extent, to depress abutting

27

properties. The one possible exception would be an expressway with a
very wide right of way which was extensively landscaped—similar, for
example, to the Westchester County Parkways. On the other hand, a
depressed expressway running between parallel streets through a blighted
residential area might have a beneficial effect on adjacent properties. Or
again, an elevated expressway between parallel streets in a blighted com-
mercial area with ample space between the structure and nearby buildings
might very well have a helpful effect. Determining whether an expressway
will be a desirable or undesirable neighbor is thus a relative matter. It
depends upon the character of the expressway, the quality of the adjacent
properties, and the nature of the buildings or uses removed to make way
for the expressway.

And finally, it should be noted that with respect to elevated express-
ways a great deal depends upon the quality of design. At their worst
elevated expressways can be heavy, oppressive, and downright ugly. By
comparison a well designed expressway structure can appear relatively
light and graceful.

Expressways Provide Incidental Advantages

Expressways frequently provide the opportunity to take advantage
of certain incidental benefits or by-products. The more important of
these include:

1. An elevated expressway not running along an existing street often
provides an opportunity to make use of the cleared land adjacent
to or underneath the structure. Landscaping and off-street park-
ing are two obvious possibilities.

2. An expressway, whether depressed or elevated, running in land
which has been cleared between two parallel streets creates an
opportunity to widen the two parallel streets with minimum cost
